intro: Polysphaeria lanceolata subsp. harleyi, commonly known as the narrow-leafed sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to certain regions of North America. It typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, where it thrives in moist, well-drained soils. The plant features linear, grass-like leaves and produces small, clustered inflorescences with tiny, wind-pollinated flowers. Its botanical structure is characteristic of the Cyperaceae family, with a rhizomatous root system and a distinct stem. It plays an important ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various invertebrates.
